column1: #Text=And I think that a parallel thing that 's going on right now that 's invisible to the culture as a whole is that we 're moving toward a more medieval way of looking at things .
#Text=Narratives are moving toward not only pinwheel narratives , but more tapestry-like narratives .
#Text=Like The Lord of the Rings , where you do n't really feature a psychological character .
#Text=If you look at the movies that were the big hits of the sixties , when I was coming up , you 've got these troubled guys that are in the center of the movie .
#Text=A guy like Steve McQueen , Dustin Hoffman in Midnight Cowboy or The Graduate ; Easy Rider , or Jack Nicholson in Five Easy Pieces .
#Text=Then the literature of the time , same thing .
#Text=Some central male character who has a lot on his mind and is upset about the ways things are going for him in the world , and he 's sort of slogging through .
#Text=My kids find stuff like that intensely boring .
#Text=They just are n't interested in psychological characters anymore .
#Text=Maybe it 's because they 're kids , but you 've got to give them credit .
#Text=I was reading Hermann Hesse when I was their age .
#Text=What their taste and what I think the culture as a whole is going toward , is more medieval .

#Text=When I say medieval , I mean lots of characters that all have archetypal qualities to them ; we do n't really know what 's going on inside their head ; they 're just kind of all acting and reacting to each other .
#Text=You look at the movies that become popular now , even going back to Pulp Fiction or anything like that , it 's , " Who cares about the central , troubled guy ?
